data.title: Corn, soybean futures steady in quiet trade
data.description:
Spot basis bids for corn and soybeans were flat in the U.S. Midwest on Thursday in quiet trade while corn and soybean futures traded on both sides of unchanged, spot checks showed.

  • The wheat basis fell at an Ohio port.

  • U.S. soybean futures rallied on Thursday to their highest level since mid-2024 on hopes for more U.S. biofuel demand and Chinese imports before the market eased in a profit-taking retreat.

  • Corn futures also declined on profit-taking and technical selling, and as weekly corn export sales fell below trade expectations, while wheat firmed following three sessions of losses.

  • The U.S. Department of Agriculture reported weekly net soybean export sales at 407,100 tons, on the low end of a range of analyst expectations.

data.title: Time for Investors to Get Defensive. Sell Staples and Buy Healthcare. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Jacob Sonenshine

Investors have plenty of reason to move into defensive stocks. The best way to do it: Sell consumer staples and buy healthcare.

For starters, the broader market is looking a little shaky. The S&P 500 has gone nowhere for about four months.

Software stocks have fallen off a cliff on the back of competitive threats from the major artificial-intelligence innovators. The market will sort thought which software vendors can stand strong and which will fall, leaving the sector somewhat of a land mine.

Meanwhile, semiconductor stocks have rallied, but they are giving back a bit of the gain Thursday, even after Nvidia's stellar guidance, indicating that chip stocks have already priced in much of their expected growth. All in all, there are plenty of potential pressure points on the S&P 500.

That's why adding less-volatile stocks to one's portfolio makes sense. The consumer staples, healthcare, and utilities sectors have consistent sales and earnings because aggregate demand for items such as toiletries, groceries, drugs, medical devices, health insurance, and electricity tends to remain relatively stable, no matter what's happening in the economy.

Buying exposure to those sectors today is less straightforward. The best strategy is to sell staples and use the proceeds to rotate into healthcare.

The Vanguard Consumer Staples Index exchange-traded fund has ripped higher — and looks unattractive. It is up 16% from a multi-month low in early January after having badly underperformed the S&P for years. It was time for staples to enjoy a catch-up trade, so in the past few weeks many market strategists have noted that the group looks overbought. The chart of the past few weeks traces a straight line upward, which means that many investors who wanted more exposure to the sector have already bought in. Going forward, demand for these shares should fade.

Fading these hot stocks now makes sense because they're more expensive in the face of weakening fundamentals. Only about 29% of analysts' revisions of 2026 earnings estimates for staples have been upward, according to FactSet, while a little more than half of 2026 revisions for all S&P 500 companies have been upward. Many staples face the possibility of declining business in the long term. Companies such as PepsiCo, Kraft-Heinz, Utz Brands, Mondelez, Hershey, General Mills, Campbell's, Conagra Brands, and J.M. Smucker are facing headwinds from healthier food options. Staples just might not deserve their current valuations.

Healthcare is a better bet. Companies in the sector don't appear vulnerable to AI or any other kind of disruption. The analyst community seems calm. About 63% of all 2026 earnings revisions for the sector have been upward.

Analysts expect growth. Medical-device makers are expected to grow sales for the long term, as demand for certain types of surgeries rises. Drugmakers are seeing a growth tailwind from GLP-1 weight-loss drugs. Health insurance recently endured a disappointing announcement from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services on funding for insurers, but the stocks look like they have already reflected that setback. Already, UnitedHealth Group, which bottomed this year at $268, has stabilized and is now at $287.

UnitedHealth is an important stock in the healthcare sector, with its $261 billion market capitalization representing almost 5% of the S&P 500 Health Care Sector index's total market cap. Further gains in UnitedHealth, which plans to replace certain costs with AI to increase its profit margins and earnings, would support gains in the State Street Health Care Select Sector SPDR ETF.

Analysts expect about 6% aggregate annual sales growth for the fund, according to FactSet. That, combined with higher margins, should drive 10% earnings growth annually.

That prospect for growth makes its valuation look tolerable. The fund trades at 20.5 times expected earnings for the coming 12 months, just under the S&P 500's 21.9 times. That's not the cheapest it's ever been, but it's normal. It often trades somewhere between a few points below the index and a few points above it. As long as earnings grow close to expectations, the stocks can rise over the next few years.

This little tweak — selling staples and buying healthcare — could do wonders for one's portfolio if the market heads south.

Write to Jacob Sonenshine at jacob.sonenshine@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Bank of Mexico Raises Forecast for 2026 Economic Growth
data.description:
By Anthony Harrup

MEXICO CITY--The Bank of Mexico increased its forecast for economic growth this year following a better-than-expected performance in the fourth quarter of 2025.

In its quarterly economic report Thursday, the central bank said it expects gross domestic product to expand 1.6% in 2026, up from its previous estimate of 1.1%. The bank left its GDP forecast at 2.0% for 2027.

The central bank said it still sees moderately faster growth, although from a higher base than previously estimated.

In the fourth quarter, Mexico's GDP grew 0.9% seasonally adjusted from the previous quarter, while third-quarter GDP was revised up to a 0.1% expansion from a previously estimated 0.3% contraction. The economy grew 0.6% in 2025.

Private consumption growth is expected to accelerate gradually in 2026, while investment is likely to remain weak, at least until the second half of the year given uncertainty about the trade relationship with the U.S. and the coming review of the U.S.-Mexico Canada Agreement, the Bank of Mexico said. Exports are expected to continue with moderate growth.

The balance of risks for growth remains tilted to the downside, the central bank said. Downside risks include greater trade uncertainty with the U.S., geopolitical conflicts that may hurt global growth and trade, and Mexico's higher tariffs on countries with which it doesn't have a trade agreement.

Upside risks to its forecast include a successful USMCA review, and the 2026 soccer World Cup which Mexico is co-hosting with the U.S. and Canada, and higher-than-expected U.S. economic growth, the central bank said.

Write to Anthony Harrup at anthony.harrup@wsj.com

data.title: Nordic American Tankers Ltd reports results for the quarter ended December 31 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• Nordic American Tankers Ltd reported quarterly adjusted earnings of 6 cents​​ per share for the quarter ended December 31, higher than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of 1 cents. The mean expectation of three analysts for the quarter was for earnings of 2 cents per share. Wall Street expected results to range from 9 cents to 18 cents per share.

  • Revenue fell 12.2% to $58.76 million from a year ago; analysts expected $72.17 million.

  • Nordic American Tankers Ltd's reported EPS for the quarter was 6 cents​.

  • The company reported a quarterly loss of $2.78 million.

  • Nordic American Tankers Ltd shares had risen by 46.5% this quarter.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had risen by about 13% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no negative revisions of earnings estimates

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 3 "strong buy" or "buy," 1 "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell." The average consensus recommendation for the oil & gas transportation services peer group is also "buy"

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Nordic American Tankers Ltd is $5.00, about 0.8% below its last closing price of $5.04

This summary was machine generated from LSEG data February 26 at 07:50 p.m. UTC. ​All figures in US dollars unless otherwise stated. data.title: Odds of early Warsh-led Fed rate cuts slide with bullish outlook
data.description:
Key points:
  • IMF sees limited scope for US rate cuts amid strong economic growth
  • CEO survey shows optimism, ongoing tariff pass-through
  • Fed sentiment could tilt more hawkish if jobs data strengthens

By Howard Schneider and Ann Saphir

Federal Reserve chair nominee Kevin Warsh's path to out-of-the-gate interest rate cuts in alignment with President Donald Trump's expectations could be narrowing amid emerging bullishness about the U.S. economy, growing CEO confidence in the outlook, and investors keying off a hawkish shift among the central bank's policymakers.

The International Monetary Fund said on Wednesday that with expected U.S. growth rising to 2.4% this year from 2.2% last year, the unemployment rate likely hovering near 4%, and inflation falling gradually, the Fed would have "only modest scope to lower the policy rate over the coming year" through a single quarter-percentage-point cut.

A new Conference Board CEO survey, meanwhile, saw a sharp jump in the outlook for both the wider economy and within each leader's industry, with little sense that large rounds of layoffs were in the offing and firms passing through price increases from the Trump administration's import tariffs - a combination that could make it harder to justify rate cuts.

Investors, meanwhile, have pushed back their bets on the timing of an initial Warsh-led rate cut, to the Fed's July 28-29 meeting from the June 16-17 gathering. Though his nomination has not been formally submitted to the Senate, Warsh is expected to be confirmed in time for the June meeting, with current Fed Chair Jerome Powell's leadership term ending in May.

The improved outlook may be good for the economy, but it could leave Warsh in the same bind as Powell, with data and his colleagues pulling in one direction and the White House pulling in another.

"The Fed's reaction function has shifted slightly more hawkish," Natixis CIB economists Christopher Hodge and Selin Aker wrote in a note, concluding the central bank could only make two quarter-percentage-point rate cuts this year, rather than the three they previously expected.

MIRAN SAYS BIG DROP IN RATES STILL POSSIBLE IN 2026

The U.S. central bank's next meeting is scheduled for March 17-18, when its policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee is expected to hold the benchmark interest rate in the 3.50%-3.75% range. New quarterly economic and rate projections also will be released at the end of that meeting.

In December, the only central bank official with a rate outlook close to the steep cuts Trump wants was Fed Governor Stephen Miran, the former head of the Trump White House's Council of Economic Advisers. Miran saw the Fed's policy rate falling to as low as the 2.00%-2.25% range in 2026. The median expectation among Miran's colleagues, by contrast, saw just one quarter-percentage-point cut as likely appropriate.

Nearly three months later, and after a strong January employment report, Miran on Thursday told the "Mornings with Maria" program on Fox Business that he still feels rates could fall a full percentage point this year through four 25-basis-point cuts, ideally sooner than later.

His outlook is partly based on his expectation for a "profoundly disinflationary" artificial intelligence boost to productivity, a "supply shock" that Warsh has also said should allow for lower rates.

"I really do not think that we have an inflation problem," despite recent inflation readings a point above the central bank's 2% target, said Miran, whose term as a Fed governor has technically expired, but who can continue to fill the job until a replacement is named. Absent some other departure from the Fed's seven-member Board of Governors, Miran's seat would be needed for Warsh to eventually come aboard.

WARSH FACES POSSIBLE DILEMMA

The minutes of the Fed's January 27-28 meeting showed little support yet for relying on AI-optimism to recast monetary policy. Staff presentations suggested a small boost in the economy's potential may be developing - the "supply shock" Miran has mentioned, but only in a measured dose - though with demand still strong enough to sustain pressure on prices.

The minutes also cited unexpected comments that several policymakers were open to the possibility that the next rate move could be a hike. In addition, Fed Governor Christopher Waller, who joined Miran in dissenting in favor of a cut at the meeting in January, said this week that if recent strong job growth is repeated, "it may be appropriate to hold the FOMC's policy rate at current levels."

The U.S. employment report for February is due to be released on March 6.

A combination of sticky inflation, a steady unemployment rate, and continued economic growth would in many ways be a comforting outcome for the Fed. Policymakers generally agree that inflation will decline and anticipate the combination of slow job growth and low rates of layoffs will yield a roughly steady unemployment rate. As long as that outlook continues, and absent any sense that public expectations about inflation are starting to shift higher, there would be little motivation to do anything other than wait.

Such an outcome could present a dilemma for Warsh, who has laid out arguments for why rates should fall and now will have to contend with a strong-willed and publicly demonstrative president who has taken the Fed chief nominee at his word. Trump said earlier this month that he had not asked Warsh to lower rates, but felt it was clear what his nominee would do.

Trump has clashed with Powell repeatedly over the president's demands for deep rate cuts, but said of Warsh last month: "I don't want to ask him that question. I think it's inappropriate ... I want to keep it nice and pure. But he certainly wants to cut rates."

The president also told NBC News he had "not much" doubt rates would fall. "We're way high," he said. Trump, who has linked his call for lower rates to hopes of financing federal government debt more cheaply and lowering costs for home mortgages, has voiced little concern about inflation that he feels has disappeared.

However, with the economy currently growing beyond estimates of its potential and inflation showing little recent progress toward the Fed's target, there's no sense of urgency at the central bank to cut rates, particularly not as steeply as Trump or Miran have suggested.

Trump's State of the Union speech to Congress earlier this week highlighted that paradox, as he trumpeted the good things that he believes have happened and those that are still to come. Many analysts agree a combination of fiscal stimulus in the form of tax cuts, ongoing deregulation, and the loose credit conditions supported by Fed rate cuts last year could spell upside for the economy - and make further reductions in borrowing costs all the less likely.

data.title: Jane Street Faces New Lawsuit: Trump Media Calls For Federal Investigation
data.description:
Jane Street, one of the world’s largest market-making firms, has come under growing scrutiny as a series of allegations have surfaced linking the company to major disruptions in the crypto market. 

The firm is already facing a federal lawsuit tied to the collapse of Terraform Labs, and now new claims circulating on social media suggest that Trump Media has accused Jane Street and other trading firms of “naked short selling” in a letter to Congress.

Jane Street Rejects Terra Allegations

The legal troubles began earlier this week. On February 23, a lawsuit was filed in the US District Court for the Southern District of New York accusing Jane Street of using confidential information obtained from Terraform Labs to shield itself from heavy losses before the Terra/Luna ecosystem unraveled in May 2022. 

According to the complaint, Jane Street allegedly leveraged insider knowledge to avoid more than $200 million in potential losses ahead of the implosion. The firm has strongly denied the accusations, characterizing the lawsuit as “desperate” and describing it as a “transparent attempt to extract money.”

Beyond the courtroom, additional claims have gained traction online. Some market participants have alleged that Jane Street manipulated Bitcoin (BTC) prices by operating an algorithm that allegedly triggered consistent sell-offs at 10 a.m. each day for months. 

According to these claims, the strategy involved pushing prices lower, triggering liquidations among retail traders, and then repurchasing Bitcoin at reduced levels in a repeated cycle. 

Naked Short Selling Inquiry

Adding another layer to the controversy, market commentator MartyParty stated on Thursday that Trump Media had sent a letter to members of Congress calling for a full investigation into Jane Street, Citadel and other firms over alleged naked short selling. 

Naked short selling refers to the practice of selling shares without first borrowing them, a tactic that is restricted under US securities law. 

As of Thursday afternoon Eastern Time, there had been no official confirmation of such a letter, nor any public statement from Trump Media, Jane Street, or Citadel verifying the claim.

Featured image from OpenArt, chart from TradingView.com

data.title: Melania Trump to chair a meeting of the UN Security Council, White House says
data.description:
Key points:
  • UN session to focus on children
  • First leader's spouse to chair the Security Council
  • US has $4 billion arrears on dues to UN
  • Melania Trump advocated for return of Ukrainian children taken to Russia

First lady Melania Trump will chair a meeting of the United Nations Security Council on Monday as the U.S. takes over the monthly rotating presidency, the White House said.

Her office said in a statement on Wednesday she will emphasize education as a way to advance tolerance and world peace in her remarks at the meeting, titled "Children, Technology, and Education in Conflict."

A U.N. spokesperson said it would be the first time a spouse of any serving world leader has chaired a meeting of the 15-member Security Council.

U.S. President Donald Trump has been a vocal critic of the United Nations since his first White House term, saying the 193-member world body was ineffective and needed reforms. The United States is billions of dollars behind in its contributions to the U.N. budget.

Asked at a regular briefing if Melania Trump's appearance was a positive sign for U.N.-U.S. relations, U.N. spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said it showed "the importance that the United States feels towards the Security Council and the subject at hand," referring to the meeting's agenda.

The first lady has stayed out of the public eye for much of Trump's presidencies but has been an advocate for children's causes in the past, including by writing a letter to Russian President Vladimir Putin in 2025 calling for the return of Ukrainian children taken to Russia during the war.

She was the subject and executive producer of a big-budget documentary film released in January .

The president struck a more conciliatory tone toward the U.N. last week at the first meeting of his Board of Peace, an initiative he said aims to resolve conflicts globally but one that many world leaders worry was designed to replace the United Nations.

  • "The Board of Peace is going to almost be looking over the United Nations and making sure it runs properly," Trump said on February 19. "We're going to strengthen up the United Nations. We're going to make sure its facilities are good
  • We're going to help them money-wise."

The United Nations last week said it received about $160 million this month of the more than $4 billion in U.S. dues arrears to the United Nations. That amount appears to have grown substantially during Trump's presidency.

Historically, the U.S. has been the biggest contributor to the U.N. budget. But under Trump, it has refused to make mandatory payments to regular and peacekeeping budgets and slashed voluntary funding to U.N. agencies.

The Security Council is the U.N. body charged with maintaining international peace and security and has the power to make legally binding decisions.

data.title: London cocoa prices slip back towards recent lows
data.description:
London cocoa futures fell on Thursday, slipping back towards a near three-year low they had touched earlier this week, while coffee prices also declined.

COCOA

* London cocoa ​​settled down 16 pounds, or 0.7%, at 2,156 pounds per metric ton. The market had set a near three-year low of 2,075 pounds on Tuesday.

* Dealers said a pick-up in selling out of Ivory Coast and Ghana, the world's top two producers, had contributed to recent weakness.

* Ivory Coast plans to bring forward the start of its cocoa mid-crop season for the first time, allowing the regulator to sharply reduce its set price paid to farmers in the hope of boosting sales, two government sources and two regulator sources told Reuters.

* New York cocoa rose 0.4% to $3,063 a ton.

* Brazil's cocoa industry group AIPC said on Thursday the government ban on Ivory Coast cocoa imports could hurt the sector, even leading to plant closures, as the country is not self-sufficient in the crop.

COFFEE

* Robusta coffee settled down $64, or 1.7%, at $3,639 a ton. The market slumped to a six-month low of $3,517 on Monday.

* Dealers said farmers in top robusta producer Vietnam remained reluctant to sell at current depressed prices.

* "Activities picked up after the (Lunar New Year) holiday, but farmers are still not selling in bulk as they are still betting on higher prices," said one trader in Vietnam.

* Arabica coffee fell 0.9% to $2.823 per pound.

* Brazilian coffee exports in the 2026/27 season could hit a record high of close to 47 million 60kg bags, driven by greater supply of arabica beans owing to a bumper crop, Hedgepoint Global Markets said in a report on Wednesday.

SUGAR

* Raw sugar ​settled down 0.18 cent, or 1.2%, at 14.41 cents per pound. The spot contract will expire on Friday.

* Dealers said despite the fall, the market was finding some support from factors including a declining outlook for production in India and the prospect of a smaller beet area in the European Union this year.

* White sugar rose 0.2% to $407.90 a ton.

data.title: This HVAC and Plumbing Stock Has Crushed Nvidia. Insiders Are Taking Profits. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Mackenzie Tatananni

Comfort Systems USA, a supplier of construction services to data centers, has become one of Wall Street's favorite ways to play the artificial-intelligence boom. Now, company insiders are taking profits on the heels of strong quarterly results.

Shares of the HVAC and plumbing company have jumped more than 2,000% over the past five years, outperforming the S&P 500 and AI darling Nvidia.

The company's latest quarterly earnings, posted on Feb. 19, gave the stock another boost. Since that report, four insiders at the firm have sold shares, and another four have signaled their intent to sell.

Chief Financial Officer George William III sold 9,000 shares for a total of $13.3 million on Monday. A Form 4 filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission shows William exercised his right to buy the shares for $42.50 apiece on the same day before selling them for roughly $1,434.97 each.

Following the transaction, William directly owned 37,824 shares or $54.9 million worth of company stock based on Wednesday's closing price of $1,450.60.

Also on Monday, company director Pablo Mercado sold 500 shares for $1,405 apiece, according to a separate filing. The sale brought Mercado's direct holdings to 3,500 shares, valued at roughly $5.1 million.

Ellen Skidmore, another director, sold 1,000 shares at $1,425 each on Tuesday, another filing shows. Skidmore directly owned 12,627 shares after the sale, worth $18.3 million.

The most recent sale occurred on Thursday when director William Sandbrook sold 2,500 shares for around $1,443.32 apiece. At last check, Sandbrook held 8,996 shares directly and 170 shares indirectly, according to an SEC filing.

Other forms filed Tuesday and Wednesday with the agency indicate that four additional insiders are gearing up to sell shares. Among them is Reed Terrence, the company's senior vice president and chief human resources officer.

Barron's reached out to Comfort Systems for comment on the transactions.

Comfort Systems provides mechanical, electrical, and plumbing services through a network of contracting businesses across the U.S.

Inside Scoop is a regular Barron's feature covering stock transactions by corporate executives and board members — so-called insiders — as well as large shareholders, politicians, and other prominent figures. Due to their insider status, these investors are required to disclose stock trades with the Securities and Exchange Commission or other regulatory groups.

Write to Mackenzie Tatananni at mackenzie.tatananni@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Pursuit Attractions and Hospitality Inc reports results for the quarter ended December 31 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• Pursuit Attractions and Hospitality Inc reported a quarterly adjusted loss of 91 cents​​ per share for the quarter ended December 31, higher than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of -82 cents. The mean expectation of four analysts for the quarter was for earnings of $2.53 per share. Wall Street expected results to range from -88 cents to -77 cents per share.

  • Revenue fell 6.5% to $241.02 million from a year ago; analysts expected $225.04 million.

  • Pursuit Attractions and Hospitality Inc's reported EPS for the quarter was a loss of 91 cents​.

  • The company reported a quarterly loss of $25.7 million.

  • Pursuit Attractions and Hospitality Inc shares had risen by 8.6% this quarter.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had risen by about 0.3% in the last three months.​

  • In the last 30 days, there have been no earnings estimate revisions by analysts covering the company.

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "strong buy" and the breakdown of recommendations is 4 "strong buy" or "buy," no "hold" and no "sell" or "strong sell." The average consensus recommendation for the leisure & recreation peer group is "buy."

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Pursuit Attractions and Hospitality Inc is $45.00, about 18.7% above its last closing price of $36.57

data.title: OLD SECOND BANCORP INC SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Old Second Bancorp, Inc., a bank holding company for Old Second National Bank, has released its 2025 10-K report, detailing significant financial performance, strategic initiatives, and operational highlights. The report underscores the company's robust growth, strategic acquisitions, and the challenges it faces in the current economic landscape.

Financial Highlights

Net Interest and Dividend Income: $292.964 million, an increase of $51.3 million or 21.2% from 2024, primarily driven by higher interest rates and the acquisition of Bancorp Financial.

Net Income Available to Common Stockholders: $80.310 million, a decrease from $85.264 million in 2024, mainly due to additional costs incurred with the Bancorp Financial acquisition.

Basic Earnings Per Share: $1.64, compared to $1.90 in 2024, reflecting the impact of acquisition-related costs.

Diluted Earnings Per Share: $1.62, compared to $1.87 in 2024, with adjusted diluted earnings per share (non-GAAP) at $2.07.

Adjusted Net Income (non-GAAP): $102.570 million, excluding acquisition-related costs and other one-time items, indicating strong underlying performance.

Business Highlights

Business Overview: Old Second Bancorp, Inc. operates as a bank holding company for Old Second National Bank, providing a full-service community banking and trust business through 55 banking centers in Illinois.

Acquisition Activities: Completed the acquisition of Bancorp Financial, Inc. on July 1, 2025, which included the merger of Evergreen Bank Group into Old Second National Bank, expanding the company's asset base and consumer lending portfolio.

Branch Expansion: Acquired five branches from First Merchants Bank in December 2024, enhancing the company's presence in Cook and DuPage counties, Illinois.

Lending Portfolio: The total loan portfolio increased significantly in 2025, with commercial real estate loans representing 36.5% of the portfolio, and a notable addition of powersport loans at 13.3% following the Evergreen acquisition.

Geographical Performance: The bank operates primarily in northeastern Illinois, with a strong presence in Cook, DeKalb, DuPage, Kane, Kendall, LaSalle, and Will counties, and has expanded its business lines nationwide through the acquisition of Bancorp Financial.

New Business Lines: The acquisition of Bancorp Financial introduced new nationwide retail business lines focused on powersport, collector car, and manufactured home lending.

Electronic Banking Services: Offers a comprehensive suite of electronic banking services, including online and mobile banking, corporate cash management, and various electronic transaction services.

Wealth Management: Provides a wide range of wealth management services, with approximately $2.29 billion in assets under administration and/or management as of December 31, 2025.

Human Capital Resources: Emphasizes employee development and retention, with 33% of employees having over ten years of tenure, supported by initiatives like the Employee Ambassadors program and community engagement activities.

Future Outlook: The company plans to continue expanding its lending portfolios and enhancing its electronic banking services, while maintaining a strong focus on community involvement and employee development.

Strategic Initiatives

Strategic Initiatives: In 2025, the company completed the acquisition of Bancorp Financial, which significantly expanded its loan portfolio and consumer lending capabilities. This strategic move was aimed at enhancing market presence and diversifying the company's financial services offerings. The acquisition included a successful systems conversion completed in October 2025, which integrated Bancorp Financial's operations into the company's existing framework.

Capital Management: The company issued 7.9 million shares of common stock and paid $48.9 million in cash as part of the consideration for the Bancorp Financial acquisition, totaling $189.4 million. This transaction increased the company's total assets to $6.90 billion and stockholders' equity to $896.8 million by year-end 2025. Additionally, the company maintained a dividend payout ratio of 15.24% in 2025, reflecting a commitment to returning value to shareholders.

Future Outlook: Looking ahead, the company plans to continue focusing on strategic acquisitions to enhance its market position and expand its service offerings. It aims to manage interest rate risk and maintain strong liquidity by optimizing its balance sheet structure. The company also intends to explore opportunities for organic growth in its loan portfolio while maintaining a disciplined approach to capital management.

Challenges and Risks

Economic Conditions: The company faces risks from economic conditions, particularly in its primary markets in Illinois, due to potential state tax increases and economic challenges. Unfavorable market conditions could lead to a deterioration in credit quality, increased loan delinquencies, and a reduction in assets under management.

Inflationary Pressures: Significant inflationary pressures in 2022 and 2023, with continued uncertainty expected in 2024 and early 2025, could lead to increased interest rates and potentially cause a recession, negatively impacting demand for loans and other financial products.

Trust and Wealth Management Vulnerability: The company's trust and wealth management business is vulnerable to changes in economic and market conditions, which could lead to reduced fees and potential legal actions from clients due to investment performance.

ESG Practices: Increasing scrutiny on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices could lead to higher operational costs and reputational risks if the company fails to meet evolving expectations.

Climate Change Risks: Climate change presents both physical and transition risks, including regulatory changes and market shifts towards a less carbon-dependent economy, which could impact the company's financial condition and operations.

Credit and Interest Rate Risks: Significant credit and interest rate risks exist, with the potential for insufficient allowance for credit losses (ACL) to absorb potential loan portfolio losses. The company's loan portfolio is heavily concentrated in commercial and residential real estate, subject to market volatility and regulatory scrutiny.

Operational Risks: The company relies on third-party vendors for critical systems, increasing exposure to cybersecurity risks. Maintaining its reputation as a community bank and competing in a highly competitive market area are also challenges.

Privacy and Technology-Related Risks: Rapid technological changes and potential cyber-attacks could disrupt operations and compromise sensitive customer information.

Growth and Strategic Risks: Implementing the company's growth strategy effectively, including potential mergers and acquisitions, could be delayed or impeded by regulatory issues.

Industry-Related Risks: Potential for increased deposit insurance premiums and adverse developments in the financial services industry, such as recent bank failures, could impact the company's operations.

Legal, Accounting, Regulatory, and Compliance Risks: Significant risks include potential noncompliance with anti-money laundering statutes and fair lending laws, posing material penalties. Changes in tax laws and regulatory environments could also adversely affect the company's financial condition.

Capital and Liquidity Risks: The company may need to raise additional capital to support growth and meet regulatory requirements, which may not be available on favorable terms. Maintaining a strong core deposit base and accessing low-cost funding sources are also challenges.

Stock Investment Risks: Potential restrictions on future dividend payments and significant fluctuations in the trading price of the stock due to various market factors.

SEC Filing: OLD SECOND BANCORP INC [ OSBC ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: Crane Co SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Crane Co, a leading manufacturer of highly engineered components for mission-critical applications in aerospace, defense, space, and process industries, has released its 2025 10-K report. The report highlights significant financial growth, strategic acquisitions, and operational achievements, while also addressing the challenges and risks faced by the company.

Financial Highlights

  • Total Net Sales: $2,305.0 million, an increase of 8.2% from 2024, driven by higher core sales, acquisitions, and favorable foreign currency translation.
  • Operating Profit: $424.2 million, up 19.2% from 2024, attributed to strong net pricing and productivity gains.
  • Net Income Attributable to Common Shareholders: $366.6 million, an increase from $294.7 million in 2024, reflecting higher net income before allocation to noncontrolling interests and favorable foreign currency translation adjustments.
  • Earnings Per Basic Share: $6.38, up from $5.15 in 2024, reflecting the increase in net income.
  • Earnings Per Diluted Share: $6.26, up from $5.05 in 2024, reflecting the increase in net income.

Business Highlights

  • Company Overview: Founded in 1855, Crane Co operates through two main segments: Aerospace & Advanced Technologies (AAT) and Process Flow Technologies (PFT).
  • Aerospace & Advanced Technologies Segment: Supplies critical components and systems for commercial aerospace, military aerospace, defense, and space markets. In 2025, the commercial market accounted for 61% of total segment sales, while the military market accounted for 39%. Sales to OEMs and aftermarket customers were 66% and 34%, respectively.
  • Process Flow Technologies Segment: Provides highly engineered fluid handling equipment for mission-critical applications, focusing on pharmaceutical, cryogenic, chemical, nuclear, and general industrial end markets.
  • Recent Acquisitions: In 2026, Crane Co acquired Druck, Panametrics, Reuter-Stokes, and optek-Danulat, enhancing capabilities in sensor-based technologies and inline process control optical measurement solutions.
  • Divestiture: Completed the sale of its Engineered Materials segment on January 1, 2025, now reported as discontinued operations.
  • Separation: On April 3, 2023, Crane Holdings, Co. separated into two independent companies: Crane NXT, Co. and Crane Co, with Crane Co listed on the NYSE under the symbol 'CR'.
  • Manufacturing Facilities: Operates manufacturing facilities in the United States, United Kingdom, Taiwan, France, and other regions, supporting global operations.
  • Future Outlook: For 2026, Crane Co expects total sales growth in the low-to-mid 20% range, driven by recent acquisitions and mid-single digit core sales growth. The AAT segment is expected to benefit from higher aircraft build rates and increased demand due to geopolitical uncertainties.
  • Geographical Performance: Serves a diverse global market with manufacturing operations and sales centers across North America, South America, Europe, the Middle East, Asia, and Australia.
  • Human Capital Resources: As of December 31, 2025, employed approximately 7,100 people worldwide, focusing on attracting, developing, and retaining exceptional talent.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Strategic Acquisitions: Pursued acquisitions to enhance its portfolio, including Druck, Panametrics, Reuter-Stokes, and optek-Danulat, integrated into existing segments.
  • Capital Management: Entered into a $900 million senior unsecured delayed draw term loan facility and a $900 million senior unsecured revolving facility, both maturing in 2030, to support acquisition strategy. Raised $1,150 million through these facilities and used the funds, along with cash on hand, to finance acquisitions. Increased annual dividend by 11% to $1.02 per share. Total net debt increased to $1,148.2 million as of December 31, 2025, with a total debt to capitalization ratio of 35.8%.
  • Future Outlook: For 2026, expects total sales growth in the low-to-mid 20% range, driven by recent acquisitions and mid-single digit core sales growth. Anticipates improved operating profit due to productivity benefits, operating leverage on higher volumes, and contributions from recent acquisitions. Plans to continue optimizing its portfolio through strategic acquisitions and divestitures, focusing on sustainable growth and shareholder value.

Challenges and Risks

  • Macroeconomic Fluctuations: Vulnerable to global economic conditions, including geopolitical risks, inflationary pressures, and changes in trade policies, which could adversely affect business operations and financial performance.
  • Demand Variability: Demand for products is subject to market conditions beyond the company's control, such as fluctuations in the aerospace and defense sectors, impacting sales and profitability.
  • International Operations: Conducting substantial business outside the U.S. exposes the company to risks such as changes in trade policies, economic and political instability, and foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations.
  • Acquisition Risks: May face challenges in identifying, completing, and integrating acquisitions, impacting growth and profitability.
  • Supply Chain Disruptions: Relies on a limited number of suppliers for components and raw materials, and disruptions could adversely affect operations.
  • Cybersecurity Threats: Information systems and data security breaches could lead to operational disruptions and reputational damage.
  • Regulatory Compliance: Must comply with various governmental regulations, and failure to do so could result in penalties and affect business operations.
  • Environmental Liabilities: Operations are subject to environmental laws, and non-compliance could lead to significant costs and liabilities.
  • Product Liability: Faces risks related to product liability claims, which could impact financial results if not adequately insured.
  • Interest Rate Fluctuations: Variable interest rates on indebtedness could increase financial expenses.

SEC Filing: Crane Co [ CR ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: Canada to Seek Bilateral Talks With Washington on Sectoral Tariffs Alongside Trade-Pact Review
data.description:
By Paul Vieira

OTTAWA--The U.S.-led review of the current trilateral North American trade pact will likely incorporate talks on a bilateral deal to ease U.S. tariffs on key industrial sectors, says the Canadian minister in charge of the country's trading relationship with Washington.

Dominic LeBlanc told a Toronto audience Thursday he expects bilateral talks to unfold alongside a review of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade agreement, known as USMCA. LeBlanc cited, for instance, talks last fall between Ottawa and Washington to ease tariffs on key sectors like steel, aluminum and automobiles, which President Trump later terminated due to anger over a Canadian ad that questioned the use of tariffs.

LeBlanc said Canada wants the U.S. to recommit to a trilateral trade pact. Furthermore, he added, "there have always been bilateral arrangements as between the three countries. That's not new… [And] we need to get a bilateral deal with the United States to take pressure off the sectoral tariffs."

The sectoral tariffs, of up to 50%, have squeezed Canada's manufacturing sector. Nonfarm payrolls data issued Thursday indicated that factories shed workers in December, for a year-over-year decline of 2.6%.

LeBlanc said he expects to meet U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer in the coming days. Greer told the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. on Tuesday that Canada will have to live with U.S. tariffs as part of a revised USMCA.

"If Canada wants to agree that we can have some level of higher tariff on them while they open up their markets to us on things like dairy and other things, then that's a helpful conversation," Greer said.

Earlier this week, LeBlanc told Canadian senators he remained optimistic about USMCA's future, noting that the White House provided an exemption to a new U.S. tariff, of up to 15%, so long as the goods entering the U.S. comply with the trilateral pact. The Bank of Canada has labeled the pending review of USMCA as a key risk to the economic outlook.

Write to Paul Vieira at paul.vieira@wsj.com

data.title: ASTRONICS CORP SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Astronics Corporation, a leading provider of advanced technologies for the global aerospace, defense, and other mission-critical industries, has released its annual Form 10-K report. The report highlights significant financial growth, strategic initiatives, and the challenges faced by the company in the past year. This comprehensive summary provides an overview of Astronics' financial performance, business operations, strategic moves, and the risks it navigates in its competitive landscape.

Financial Highlights

Astronics Corporation reported robust financial performance for the year, driven by strong demand in its Aerospace segment:

  • Sales: $862.1 million, reflecting a growth driven by continued strength in demand for the Aerospace segment primarily from the Commercial Transport market.
  • Gross Profit: $258.2 million, with a Gross Margin of 29.9%, up from 27.7% in the previous year, indicating improved production efficiencies and favorable mix.
  • Income (Loss) from Operations: $76.4 million, a significant improvement from $26.5 million in the prior year, driven by higher sales volume and cost management.
  • Net Income: $29.4 million, compared to a net loss of $16.2 million in the previous year, reflecting strong operating profit and lower interest expense.
  • Diluted Earnings (Loss) Per Share: $0.81, improved from a loss of $(0.46) per share in the prior year, supported by the strength in operating profit and reduced interest expense.

Business Highlights

The company's business performance was marked by significant achievements and operational developments:

  • Revenue Segments: The Aerospace segment's sales were primarily driven by the Commercial Transport market, accounting for 75% of sales, followed by the military aircraft market at 15%, and the general aviation market at 9%. The Test Systems segment supports aerospace and defense, communications, and mass transit industries.
  • Geographical Performance: Principal operations are located in the U.S., Canada, France, and Germany, with engineering offices in Ukraine and India. The company has not experienced significant disruption in Ukraine due to the ongoing conflict.
  • Sales Units: The Aerospace segment experienced increased demand for cabin power, lighting and safety, seat motion, and system certification products. The Test Systems segment saw a decline in sales due to lower demand in U.S. Army and Marine Corps radio test programs.
  • New Product Launches: The acquisition of Bühler Motor Aviation expanded the product portfolio to include aircraft seat actuation systems, actuators, electronics, control panels, pneumatic systems, and lighting.
  • New Production Launches: The company initiated simplification activities in the Aerospace segment, including footprint rationalization and portfolio shaping, which involved restructuring charges and inventory reduction.
  • Future Outlook: The company anticipates growth in the Aerospace segment driven by increased aircraft build rates and airline spending on fleet improvements. The Test Systems segment is expected to pursue large, multi-year projects to drive future growth.

Strategic Initiatives

Astronics Corporation has undertaken several strategic initiatives to enhance its market position and financial stability:

  • Simplification Activities: In 2025, Astronics initiated simplification activities in the Aerospace segment, focusing on footprint rationalization and portfolio shaping. This included restructuring charges related to inventory reduction and impairment of long-lived assets.
  • Acquisitions: The company completed acquisitions of Envoy Aerospace and BMA to enhance its capabilities in FAA ODA services and aircraft seat actuation systems, respectively.
  • Capital Management: Astronics replaced its ABL Revolving Credit Facility with a new $300 million senior secured Revolving Credit Facility, which includes various financial covenants. The company issued $225 million of 2031 Convertible Notes, which do not bear interest and mature in 2031, and entered into capped call transactions to mitigate potential dilution. Additionally, Astronics partially repurchased $132 million of its 2030 Convertible Notes. The company did not pay any dividends and has no plans to institute a cash dividend program, preferring to retain capital for investment in technology, acquisitions, and debt retirement.
  • Future Outlook: Astronics plans to continue aligning its operations with production expectations from major customers like Boeing and Airbus. The company is monitoring geopolitical tensions and their potential impact on operations. It aims to maintain sufficient liquidity through expected operating results and available borrowing capacity, while also exploring actions to enhance profitability and cash generation, such as manufacturing efficiency initiatives and cost-reduction measures.

Challenges and Risks

Astronics Corporation faces several challenges and risks in maintaining its competitive position in the aerospace and defense industries:

  • Market Risks: The company is heavily reliant on Boeing, which accounted for 10.4% of sales in 2025. Any reduction in business with Boeing could significantly impact sales and earnings. Additionally, the cyclical nature of the aerospace market, coupled with economic conditions, conflicts, and events, poses risks to the company's operating results.
  • Operational Risks: Supply chain constraints, cybersecurity threats, and the need to adapt to technological changes are significant operational risks. The company is also dealing with the impact of customer bankruptcies and restructuring charges related to simplification activities in the Aerospace segment.
  • Regulatory Risks: Compliance with government contracts and potential changes in tax laws present regulatory risks. The company also faces strategic risks related to its acquisition strategy and the integration of acquired businesses.
  • Financial Risks: The potential for covenant violations under its Revolving Credit Facility and the impact of its Convertible Notes on liquidity are key financial risks. The company is also exposed to foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations and interest rate changes, which could impact its cost of capital and financial flexibility.
  • Geopolitical Risks: Geopolitical tensions, such as the Russia-Ukraine conflict, and potential changes in trade policies could further exacerbate these risks.

SEC Filing: ASTRONICS CORP [ ATRO ] - 10-K - Feb. 26, 2026

data.title: $BBNX ALERT: Block & Leviton Launches Securities Fraud Investigation After 35%+ Drop; Beta Bionics Investors Encouraged to Contact the Firm
data.description:
BOSTON, MA / ACCESS Newswire / February 26, 2026 / Block & Leviton is investigating Beta Bionics, Inc. for potential securities law violations. Investors who have lost money in their Beta Bionics, Inc. investment should contact the firm to learn more about how they might recover those losses. For more details, visit https://blockleviton.com/cases/bbnx.

What is this all about?

Shares of Beta Bionics fell over 35% in January, after the company released preliminary Q4 2025 topline results showing new patient starts of at least 5,581, which trailed Wall Street expectations. In a later filing, Beta Bionics disclosed that it received an FDA warning letter following a June 2025 inspection of its Irvine, California facility, which cited quality system and reporting issues related to the iLet platform. Block & Leviton is investigating.

Who is eligible?

Anyone who purchased Beta Bionics, Inc. common stock and has seen their shares fall may be eligible, whether or not they have sold their investment. Investors should contact Block & Leviton to learn more.

What is Block & Leviton doing?

Block & Leviton is investigating whether the Company committed securities law violations and may file an action to attempt to recover losses on behalf of investors who have lost money.

What should you do next?

If you've lost money on your investment, you should contact Block & Leviton to learn more via our case website, by email at shareholders@blockleviton.com, or by phone at (888) 256-2510.

Whistleblower?

If you have non-public information about Beta Bionics, Inc., you should consider assisting in our investigation or working with our attorneys to file a report with the Securities Exchange Commission under their whistleblower program. Whistleblowers who provide original information to the SEC may receive rewards of up to 30% of any successful recovery. For more information, contact Block & Leviton at shareholders@blockleviton.com or by phone at (888) 256-2510.

Why should you contact Block & Leviton?

Block & Leviton is widely regarded as one of the leading securities class action firms in the country. Our attorneys have recovered billions of dollars for defrauded investors and are dedicated to obtaining significant recoveries on behalf of our clients through active litigation in the federal courts across the country. Many of the nation's top institutional investors hire us to represent their interests. You can learn more about us at our website www.blockleviton.com, call (888) 256-2510 or email shareholders@blockleviton.com with any questions.

This notice may constitute attorney advertising.

CONTACT:

BLOCK & LEVITON LLP

260 Franklin St., Suite 1860

Boston, MA 02110

Phone: (888) 256-2510

Email: shareholders@blockleviton.com

SOURCE: Block & Leviton LLP

View the original press release on ACCESS Newswire
